questions.question: Error Detection and Correction is a primary topic covered in the Data Link Layer.
The problem of marking the start and end of each frame is generally solved before addressing error control mechanisms.
Ensuring frames are delivered to the network layer in the proper order is a major concern of the Data Link Layer.
A positive acknowledgement (ACK) indicates that the frame has arrived safely at the receiver.
A negative acknowledgement (NAK) implies that the frame was successfully delivered without corruption.
Hardware troubles on a physical link can cause a data frame to vanish completely during transmission.
Control frames are utilized to provide necessary feedback from the receiver to the sender.
A negative acknowledgement signal requires the sender to transmit the specific frame again.
If a frame is lost due to malfunctioning hardware, a sender without a timeout mechanism will hang indefinitely waiting for an acknowledgement.
The implementation of a timer prevents the sender from hanging indefinitely if a frame or its acknowledgment is lost.
If an acknowledgment is lost, the sender will eventually time out and retransmit the frame.
Without sequence numbers, a receiver might mistakenly accept a retransmitted duplicate frame as a new one.
Sequence numbers are used to distinguish retransmissions from original frames in reliable delivery protocols.
Flow control is a critical design issue in the data link layer to prevent receiver buffer overflow.
A sender can safely transmit frames at the maximum line rate regardless of the receiver's processing speed.
Flow control mechanisms prevent a fast sender from out-pacing a slow receiver.
Feedback-based flow control requires the receiver to send information back to the sender regarding its status.
In feedback-based flow control, the receiver explicitly tells the sender when it is ready to receive more data.
Rate-based flow control relies on a built-in protocol mechanism to limit the data transmission rate rather than direct feedback for every frame.
Transmission errors are expected to remain a challenge in network communication for the foreseeable future.
One of the fundamental strategies to handle errors is to include redundant information in the transmitted block.
Error correcting codes contain enough redundancy to allow the receiver to deduce the original transmitted data.
Error detecting codes include enough redundancy to pinpoint and correct the specific bits that were flipped.
Error codes are examined in the Link Layer because it is the first layer where reliability for grouped bits (frames) is addressed.
Error Detection and Correction codes are frequently used in the link, network, and transport layers to ensure data integrity.
Many network protocol standards derive their error-checking codes from established fields of mathematics.
Hamming codes are a widely used type of Error Detection and Correction code.
Reed-Solomon codes are a common type of Error Detection and Correction code used in networking.
A data frame typically consists of 'm' data bits and 'r' redundant bits added for error management.
A block code computes 'r' check bits solely as a mathematical function of the 'm' data bits.
In a systemic code, the original data bits are sent directly along with the computed check bits.
Hamming codes are designed for error correction, not just simple detection.
Redundant bits are extra bits added to a transmission to ensure that the original data can be recovered if errors occur.
The formula used to calculate the minimum number of redundant bits (r) for correcting a single bit in a message of 'm' bits is 2^r >= m + r + 1.
In Hamming code, bit positions that are powers of 2 (1, 2, 4, 8, etc.) are reserved for parity bits.
Parity bit 1 covers bit positions that have a 1 in the least significant bit of their binary representation.
In an even parity scheme, the parity bit is set to 0 if the total number of ones in the checked positions is already even.
In an even parity scheme, if the count of data 1's is odd, the parity bit is set to 1 to make the total count even.
Hamming codes can be configured to perform error detection for multiple bits.
Standard Hamming codes can correct burst errors by using an interleaving trick.
A single parity bit can detect an odd number of errors (1, 3, 5, etc.) but cannot detect an even number of errors.
Two-dimensional parity checking allows for the detection of errors in both rows and columns of a data block.
Checksums are a common method of error detection where the transmitter computes a numerical value based on the message content.
If a received checksum does not match the checksum sent in the frame, the transmission is considered corrupted.
In the standard checksum process, the data is divided into segments of fixed bit length for summation.
The IP network layer checksum is typically implemented using 1's complement arithmetic.
If the final result of a 1's complement checksum calculation at the receiver is zero, the data is typically accepted.
Cyclic Redundancy Check (CRC) is generally more thorough and effective at detecting errors than a simple checksum.
The mathematical basis for CRC involves viewing bit strings as polynomials and performing binary division.
Stop and Wait ARQ is a protocol that offers both error control and flow control.
Stop and Wait ARQ is logically a sliding window protocol with a window size of 1.
Propagation Delay is the time it takes for a single bit to travel physically from the sender to the receiver.
Round Trip Time (RTT) is approximately calculated as twice the one-way propagation delay.
A sender in a Stop and Wait protocol must receive an acknowledgment for the current packet before sending the next one.
Stop and Wait ARQ effectively resolves the issue of delayed acknowledgments by using sequence numbers.
The Stop and Wait protocol only requires a single-bit sequence number (0 and 1) to function correctly.
The throughput of a Stop and Wait protocol is limited to one data frame per Round Trip Time (RTT).
Stop and Wait ARQ becomes highly inefficient on links where the Bandwidth-Delay Product is large.
Pipelining or Sliding Window protocols allow multiple frames to be in transit simultaneously to improve efficiency.
The total cycle time for a single packet in a Stop and Wait acknowledgment cycle is Transmission Delay + (2 * Propagation Delay).
